comments.commentBody: Just fire them without pensions.

As long as these cops aren't punished for this criminal behavior with serious fines and /or jail time they will continue doing it. As long as police departments aren't punished this will continue. Training shmaining these cops like doing this stuff; it gives them a high, with no downside, i.e. no punishment. The key word here is impunity.

I'm more of a 'meh'. . . did it, nothing special. IJSSEL only from the crosses.

EDEN clue was a good one, the AMIGO clue was weak. If the constructor thought there were too many Franco-Crosswordese, who am I to disagree?

I read somewhere that Rev. Jenkins' salary goes to his religious order, not to him personally, so maybe he's got a conflict of interest in deciding whether athletes playing at his school might want to receive some money in addition to their education?

@David Underwood:

"And if things work out we wont have to listen to most of them for awhile after 2016."

Don't count on it. We still have to listen to Cheney.
Serena haters oh so  thinly veiled - appalling as they revel in her loss.  She  will soldier on as did her forebear, Ms. Gibson.
I don't begrudge the winner but I'm so sorry Serena lost.

It has been great to see Vinci and Federer play with pure joy. Love of the game, love of the crowd. Serena is angry and burdened. Angry, too, that she had no control over the match. Vinci played a different game and Serena did not like that. You could see her anger and frustration coming through.

Laura, ITA with you i Don't think she enjoyed the Open either  the pressure they everyone was putting on her was just crazy I think it killed the joy. I'm not saying she wouldn't have loved to get the slam but it seemed she only was really happy when talking about the Serena Slam and the crowd. As for the  winner good for her she play a good match and won.

Tough loss for sure. But I think Serena did not enjoy the Open. She lost the joy early. The sister drama, the rain, the pressure of the GS: not excuses, but all factors. Vinci,  the opposite: playing as if she has nothing to lose. I was so struck by her outfit -- beyond simple - -almost plain. But a game, at least today, like her namesake: da Vinci. A pleasure to see her game and her wonderful spirit. I will root for her tomorrow.
Serena looked like a deer in the headlights on the last two points. She knew she was done. I felt so bad for her.

Nice article, Dan. You bring up air of interesting points that will probably be hotly debated in the coming years. While it will probably be more difficult than it seems, I like Rev. Jenkins' initiative that is so different from Power 5 conference teams. It also brings up a question of self-reflection on the part of the university. Does ND think that they are above the fold enough to go against the money machine that is the NCAA in the near future? Or do they think that they will still attract quality student-athletes if they don't go via the pay-for-play route? Will their goal still be to attract these types of students? This article was thought provoking and provides insight into perhaps the greatest conundrum facing sports today.
What makes you think that these two situations are mutually exclusive?
John, at one time or another, it's just time TO GO!  And lingering on may not be the best option for some people.  They may want to end the suffering posthaste.
Well, John, I do hope the scientists find a way to treat and cure old age before I hit a hundred.  Of two hundred.  Or three hundred.  Or ...

Thank god , early medicine pioneers and scientists didn't think about suicide, instead finding a way to treat illness. Hope this decision will not deter other scientists to find medicines to cure illnesses.

I predict confidently this match up will result in increased interest in tennis in USA, if that's possible. Possibly opened up some seats for folks who wouldn't have a prayer of outbidding yesterday morning. Myself, this is the most excitement I've had since I was trying to sell an OK Head racquet and the fellow actually was
comparing his ground strokes! I never regretted not being able to sell that pony.

Don't bet on it! I've played and been a fan of this great athletic sport for many years! It has always gotten essentially bad press coverage, the USTA has become more of  its' all about the money, and more importantly for today, many Americans have become lazier, and well, a sport like this that requires an individual sustained attention span, just look around and notice what's the latest thing your neighbor is tethered to! Not recipes for the for the growth of tennis from any angle!!!
Wow.  This feels like when Buster Douglas beat Mike Tyson.

WOW! What an accomplishment for these two Italian 'older' women. Pennetta vs Vinci should be a great match and worthy of high TV ratings. I would happily create an Italian meal if they ever come to Seattle.

I'll be pulling for Vinci — anyone who has beaten Serena Williams on the verge of a Grand Slam deserves to win the Open. Both of these ladies must be flying over the moon tonight. Hope they both can get some sleep and play the match of their lives on Saturday. Brava Italia!
Yes, it is a historic event, the first all-Italian US open final, and as the article notes, a Grand Slam first for an all-Italian final.  Not all history is made by Americans.

So "the match is no longer a historic event" because two not-so-known, not-so-glamorous and, most important, not-American women will play and therefore the match is not worth watching anymore. Wow, as an Italian, this is exactly what I would call racist attitude.
This said, to Flavia e Roberta: bravissime!! I hope you both will enjoy this once-in-a-lifetime evening!

Not personally knowing Ms Williams I'll reserve judgment on her "character"(despite what Michelle Obama says). But perhaps the feelings of those less enthralled and concerned with her every mood and movement has less to do with "racist attitudes" and more to do with reprehensible behavior - like menacing and threatening a line judge with a tennis racket while spewing obscenities. And refusing to apologize.

It must be exciting for the Italians when two nationals ranked below twenty get to play in the final. I won't be watching, however. I was excited for Serena to complete the slam and solidify the greatness of her career. Alas, the match is no longer a historic event. Rather, it is a bit of a sad one for all except those who actually are familiar with one or both players.   Many are quick to applaud Serena's loss without even knowing anything about the victor. For the most part I chalk this stance up to racist attitudes, especially those that criticize Serena's character. Serena is one of the greatest champions of any sport and we should all admire her drive and her person. We are proud, as Michelle Obama says.

Classy = white,
Just say that.
It couldn't possibly be because, after all these years, tennis fans feel a certain familiarity with Serena -- I mean, Ms. Williams -- could it?
More of the same... moving the goal posts.

short classic to spice up 36D

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ON0JQQUXttY

Bratton is a politician.  He knows he can't succeed as commissioner without the support of the police - they are his constituency not the public.  The influentials among the public (i.e white, wealthy and living in a good neighborhood) just want the police to keep the great unwashed away and don't particularly care how they do it, until they get slammed to the ground or caught in the crossfire.

I've never been too wild about the Williams sisters, either, but they started out pretty rough and did really well. As for McEnroe, all I can say is he was a sheer joy to watch in his heyday, one of the most exciting players I've ever seen. I think he really did love to play but his intensity might have hid that a lot.
Agreed. It's sad.
A retuning indeed. How can tennis player ever maintain their dignity after a year when they win 3 of the 4 majors and reach the semis in the fourth.

Unfortunately, death -- like a lot of things in life -- cannot be "gamed". Nobody, not even doctors, know when the end is coming. I am sorry about your experiences; they were sad and perhaps unfortunate. But I've seen both pets AND people die on their own, die peacefully -- die in pain, die miserably -- die in hospice (or for a pet, put to sleep at a vet clinic). There is no "one way" that is right or EVEN POSSIBLE for everyone in every situation.

Nobody in hospice will force morphine on a patient who is cognizant and can refuse it. Your mom clearly wanted to live every day allotted to her, no matter what -- surely you are NOT arguing to taking those days away from her, on the grounds that her death was upsetting to YOU?

Dr. Kevorkian was a nut, and he was obsessed with death to the point of mental illness. And he influenced some people to commit suicide in a highly questionable way -- for example, people who were not dying, but depressed! or who had treatable conditions.

What you are arguing for her is not "assisted suicide" (which is only for those patients like Ms. Maynard who are entirely in their right mind, and physically capable of taking the drugs) but for euthanasia -- for "putting down" an unfortunate relative when they are very sick or very old. That is NOT this bill, and I don't ever want to see human beings treated as if they were animals.

Actually, as one nears the end now, I believe doctors can quicken the exit with more medication and I believe they often do that, regardless of finances as I read in some comments. I think it has more to do with the Hospice.

Concerned Citizen....I'm sorry, but doctors do know when the end is coming as there are clear signs. After having held the hands of seven dying people I've seen the signs over and over. You don't want to see people being treated as if they were animals. Let me tell you, there is not a whole lot of difference in the way animals and people should be treated Concerned Citizen. I've  seen people die peacefully without pain. I've seen all my animals die peacefully without pain, I'm sure. Every situation is different as you state. True, while morphine is the Hospice med, if you tell them you refuse it, they will stop, but you must know what they are giving you before they give it to you. And no, they automatically feel they need to give pain meds and do so without announcing what they are giving, under doctor's orders. The ONLY part of my Loving Mother's death that was upsetting to me Concerned Citizen was watching her have a Stroke, a Heart Attack and listening to her drown in her own fluid, and nobody doing anything to assist her. I would not say my dear Mom was enjoying her day, at all! Concerned Citizen, you are totally wrong about Dr. Kervorkian. My Mother was entirely in her right mind until the very end when she started the normal process of crossing over, she was NOT an unfortunate relative, she was not very sick or very old, just a normal dying person. I AM all for "Assisted Suicide" which is Equal to Euthanasia, just called a different name.

Aside from terminal, regular hospice patients can linger on. My Mother was in Hospice for 3.5 months. She did not want to die and fought it to the end. A very strong lady, walked and ate until days before her death. Morphine is the med of hospice, as though all hospice patients are in pain. She wasn't in pain, perhaps until the end, at which time she should have gone FSSSSSSSSSSST! I watched her have a stroke, heart attack, and drown in her own fluid, all in a short period of time just before her death. She lit up like a tomato on morphine, so they discontinued that and pushed oxycodone down her throat to stop any pain. Some people don't have pain, but I'd say my Mother suffered pain in the end. I will not do that, except the pain I cause myself while I can take care of the situation. Poor Dr. Korvorkian! He was so right. Doctors pretty much know when the end is coming. I've held the hand of 7 dying people, I know when the end is near.  I've had animals all my life and not a one died on their own, along with their Vets, we've always had to make the decision when it was time for them to go on.
Federer had an amusing answer to the question about the pressure one feels as number 1. He said he'd rather have that #1 "good" pressure than the pressure of someone who has lost 10 in a row.

Italy should give BOTH Roberta Vinci and Flavia Pennetta (not just the winner) the equivalent of a 5th Ave. parade in Rome.  For the first time in history, an all Italian Grand Slam final.  Meraviglioso!  (Wonderful).
That's funny... Yeah they were making her out to be inevitable to win ... Just like Clinton getting the dem nomination... Some things just ain't gonna happen!!!!
